sources.full: The Winter Halo's Wizard Subclass Overhaul

subclassFeature.name: School of Abjuration
entries: The School of Abjuration emphasizes magic that blocks, banishes, or protects. Detractors of this school say that its tradition is about denial, negation rather than positive assertion. You understand, however, that ending harmful effects, protecting the weak, and banishing evil influences is anything but a philosophical void. It is a proud and respected vocation.

Called abjurers, members of this school are sought when baleful spirits require exorcism, when important locations must be guarded against magical spying, and when portals to other planes of existence must be closed.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Ward
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can weave magic around yourself for protection. When you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} an abjuration spell of 1st level or higher, you can simultaneously use a strand of the spell's magic to create a magical ward on yourself that lasts until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}. The ward starts off with hit points equal to {@b twice your wizard level + your Intelligence modifier + your proficiency bonus (minimum of one)}, and when you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} an abjuration spell of 1st level or higher, the ward gains a number of hit points equal to twice the level of the spell. Whenever you take damage, the ward takes the damage instead. The ward has the same damage resistances, immunities, and vulnerabilities as you. If this damage reduces the ward to 0 hit points, you take any remaining damage. While the ward has 0 hit points, it can't absorb damage, but its magic remains. Once you create the ward, you can't create it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Projected Ward
entries: Starting at 6th level, the range and duration of all of your abjuration spells double, and when a creature that you can see within 30 feet of you takes damage, you can use your reaction to cause your {@subclassFeature Arcane Ward|Wizard|PHB|Abjuration|WHW|2|WHW} to absorb that damage if the ward has more than 0 hit points. If this damage reduces the ward to 0 hit points, the warded creature takes any remaining damage.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Abjuration
entries: Beginning at 10th level, when you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} an abjuration spell that requires you to make an ability check (such as in {@spell Counterspell} and {@spell Dispel Magic}), skill check, or saving throw, you can add your proficiency bonus to the roll. If you would already add your proficiency bonus, it is doubled. Additionally, once per round, you can either use your {@subclassFeature Projected Ward|Wizard|PHB|Abjuration|WHW|6|WHW} feature or {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} one abjuration spell with a casting time of a reaction without using your reaction.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Bastion
entries: Starting at 14th level, you have {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} on any ability checks, skill checks, and saving throws made against spells.
Furthermore, you have resistance against the damage of spells.

When a creature that you can see within 30 feet of you has to make an ability check, skill check, or saving throw against a spell, you can use your {@subclassFeature Projected Ward|Wizard|PHB|Abjuration|WHW|6|WHW} feature as a reaction to grant them {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage}. Any damage dealt by the spell is absorbed by your Arcane Ward. If this damage reduces the ward to 0 hit points, the warded creature takes any remaining damage.

subclassFeature.name: School of Conjuration
entries: As a conjurer, you favor spells that produce objects and creatures out of thin air. You can conjure billowing clouds of killing fog or summon creatures from elsewhere to fight on your behalf. As your mastery grows, you learn spells of transportation and can teleport yourself across vast distances, even to other planes of existence, in an instant.

subclassFeature.name: Minor Conjuration
entries: Starting at 2nd level when you select this school, you can use your action to conjure up an inanimate object in your hand or on the ground in an unoccupied space that you can see within 10 feet of you.

This object can be no larger than 3 feet on a side and weigh no more than 20 pounds, and its form must be that of a nonmagical object that you have seen. The object is visibly magical, radiating dim light out to 5 feet, and is worth 0 gp for the purpose of being used as a spell component.

To conjure an object, you must have at least a vague understanding of how it works and is created; for example, most wizards are likely to know roughly how a {@item Chain (10 feet)|PHB|metal chain} or {@item breastplate|PHB} is made, or how an {@item arcane focus|PHB} is constructed, but not how an {@item antimatter rifle|DMG} is made. Additionally, the object you create cannot be worth more than 400 gp. Hazardous materials conjured by this feature do not retain their hazardous properties and only deal damage appropriate to the damage dealt by being crushed, stabbed, or cut by the object. For example, a 20 pound ball of half-cooled magma created by this spell does not deal any fire damage, but it can deal damage appropriate for an improvised weapon when thrown, and it might do much more damage when dropped off a cliff onto someone's head at terminal velocity. Poison generally acts as an inert paste or liquid, and explosives do not detonate. A conjured block of ice does not deal extra cold damage to a fire elemental. These general rules of thumb hold true for other exotic materials like powerful acids, normally radioactive substances, and more. The object disappears after 1 hour, when you use this feature again, when you use an action to dismiss it, or if it takes any damage. Armor does not take damage when it is used for its intended purpose. Starting at 14th level, you can create an object that weighs up to 200 pounds and is up to five feet on a side.

subclassFeature.name: Benign Transportation
entries: Starting at 6th level, the range and duration of all of your Conjuration spells double, and you can use your bonus action to teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space that you can see. Alternatively, you can choose a space within range that is occupied by a Small or Medium creature. If that creature is willing, you both teleport, swapping places.

Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}. However, you gain additional uses of this feature when you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} a conjuration spell of 1st level or higher, which lasts until you use them or take a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

Additionally, when you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} a conjuration spell that can teleport a creature, any of your summoned creatures within range of the spell (if the range of the spell is Self, Touch, or is less than 30 feet, the range of this feature becomes 30 feet) can use their reaction to also teleport as if they used the spell.

subclassFeature.name: Focused Conjuration
entries: Beginning at 10th level, when you are conscious and {@condition concentration|PHB|concentrating} on a conjuration spell, your {@condition concentration} can't be broken as a result of taking damage.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Summons
entries: Starting at 14th level, any creature or object that you summon or create with a conjuration spell gains temporary hit points equal to {@b your Wizard Level + your Intelligence Modifier + your proficiency bonus + the spell's level (minimum of one)}, and you add your Intelligence modifier (minimum of one) to any damage they deal. If you would already add your Intelligence modifier to the damage, then it is doubled.

subclassFeature.name: Minor Conjuration Improvement
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can create an object that weighs up to 200 pounds and is up to five feet on a side.

subclassFeature.name: School of Divination
entries: The counsel of a diviner is sought by royalty and commoners alike, for all seek a clearer understanding of the past, present, and future. As a diviner, you strive to part the veils of space, time, and consciousness so that you can see clearly. You work to master spells of discernment, remote viewing, supernatural knowledge, and foresight.

subclassFeature.name: Portent
entries: Starting at 2nd level when you choose this school, glimpses of the future begin to press in on your awareness. When you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}, roll two {@dice d20|d20s} and record the numbers rolled. You can replace any attack roll, saving throw, or ability check made by you or a creature that you can see with one of these foretelling rolls. You can replace a roll in this way only once per round.
Each foretelling roll can be used only once. When you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}, you lose any unused foretelling rolls.

subclassFeature.name: The Third Eye
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use your bonus action to increase your powers of {@skill perception}. When you do so, you gain the following benefits, which lasts a number of minutes equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of one). You can't use the feature again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

items.name: Ethereal Senses
entries: You gain {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet. If you already have {@sense darkvision}, then this extends it by 60 feet. You can also see through magical darkness that is within your {@sense darkvision}. In addition, you gain {@sense truesight} and {@sense blindsight} out to a range of 10 feet. If you already have {@sense truesight} or {@sense blindsight}, then this extends it by 10 feet.

items.name: Greater Comprehension
entries: You can understand, speak, and write any language.

subclassFeature.name: Expert Diviner
entries: At 10th level, you can {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} one of your {@subclassFeature Divination Tradition Spells|Wizard|PHB|Abjuration|WHW|2|WHW|Tradition Spells} without expending a spell slot once per {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}. If you want to upcast the spell, you must expend a spell slot as normal.

Additionally, during a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}, you can replace one of your {@subclassFeature Divination Tradition Spells|Wizard|PHB|Abjuration|WHW|2|WHW|Tradition Spells} with a divination spell from any spell list, but the spell chosen must be the same level as the {@subclassFeature Divination Tradition Spells|Wizard|PHB|Abjuration|WHW|2|WHW|Tradition Spell} you replaced it with.

subclassFeature.name: Great Portent
entries: Starting at 14th level, the visions in your dreams intensify and paint a more accurate picture in your mind of what is to come. You roll three {@dice d20|d20s} for your {@subclassFeature Portent|Wizard|PHB|Abjuration|WHW|2|WHW} feature, rather than two. You can also save any unused foretelling rolls.
Additionally, you can use your Great Portent feature twice per round, and you can use it on any die roll.

subclassFeature.name: School of Enchantment
entries: As a member of the School of Enchantment, you have honed your ability to magically entrance and beguile other people and monsters. Some enchanters are peacemakers who bewitch the violent to lay down their arms and charm the cruel into showing mercy. Others are tyrants who magically bind the unwilling into their service. Most enchanters fall somewhere in between.

subclassFeature.name: Hypnotic Gaze
entries: Starting at 2nd level when you choose this school, your soft words and enchanting gaze can magically enthrall another creature. As an action, choose one creature that you can see within 30 feet of you. If the target can see or hear you, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your wizard spell save DC or be {@condition charmed} by you until the end of your next turn. The {@condition charmed} creature's speed drops to 0, and the creature is {@condition incapacitated} and visibly dazed.

On subsequent turns, you can use your bonus action to maintain this effect, extending its duration until the end of your next turn. However, the effect ends if you move more than 30 feet away from the creature, if the creature can neither see nor hear you, or if the creature takes damage.

Once the effect ends, or if the creature succeeds on its initial saving throw against this effect, you can't use this feature on that creature again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Instinctive Charm
entries: Beginning at 6th level, the range and duration of all of your enchantment spells doubles, and when a creature you can see within 30 feet of you makes an attack roll against you, you can use your reaction to divert the attack, provided that another creature is within the attack's range. The attacker must make a Wisdom saving throw against your wizard spell save DC. On a failed save, the attacker must target the creature that is closest to it, not including you or itself. If multiple creatures are closest, you choose which one to target.
On a successful save, you can't use this feature on the attacker again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.
Creatures that can't be {@condition charmed} are immune to this effect.

subclassFeature.name: Split Enchantment
entries: Starting at 10th level, when you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} an enchantment spell of 1st level or higher that can target a creature, you can target an additional creature within range of the spell.

subclassFeature.name: Alter Memories
entries: At 14th level, you gain the ability to make a creature unaware of your magical influence on it. When you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} an enchantment spell to {@condition charmed|PHB|charm} one or more creatures, you can alter one creature's understanding so that it remains unaware of being {@condition charmed}.

Additionally, once before the spell expires, you can use your action to try to make the chosen creature forget some of the time it spent {@condition charmed}. The creature must succeed on an Intelligence saving throw against your wizard spell save DC or lose a number of hours of its memories equal to your Intelligence modifier + your proficiency bonus (minimum 1). You can make the creature forget less time, and the amount of time can't exceed the duration of your enchantment spell.

subclassFeature.name: School of Evocation
entries: You focus your study on magic that creates powerful elemental effects such as bitter cold, searing flame, rolling thunder, crackling lightning, and burning acid. Some evokers find employment in military forces, serving as artillery to blast enemy armies from afar. Others use their spectacular power to protect the weak, while some seek their own gain as bandits, adventurers, or aspiring tyrants.

subclassFeature.name: Sculpt Spells
entries: Beginning at 2nd level, you can create pockets of relative safety within the effects of your evocation spells. When you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} an evocation spell that affects other creatures that you can see, you can choose a number of them equal to your Intelligence modifier + the spell's level (minimum of one). The chosen creatures automatically succeed on their saving throws against the spell, and they take no damage if they would normally take half damage on a successful save.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Evocation
entries: Starting at 6th level, the range and duration of all of your evocation spells doubles, and you can add your Intelligence modifier + the spell's level (minimum of one) to the damage of any wizard evocation spell that you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast}.

subclassFeature.name: Adaptive Spells
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you have learned to adapt your spells to where even those that would have avoided the brunt of the damage are affected. When a creature succeeds on a saving throw against an evocation spell of 5th level or lower that you've {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast}, they still take full damage (or half if the spell normally does no damage on a successful save), but suffers no additional effect from the spell. Additionally, on a failed save, the spell ignores damage resistances, but not immunities, and the spell does an extra die of damage to creatures that are not resistant or immune to the damage.

subclassFeature.name: Overchannel
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can increase the power of some of your spells. When you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} a wizard spell of 5th level or lower that deals damage and isn't a cantrip, you can deal maximum damage with that spell.

The first time you do so, you suffer no adverse effect. If you use this feature again before you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}, you take {@damage 2d12} necrotic damage for each level of the spell, immediately after you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} it. Each time you use this feature again before finishing a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}, the necrotic damage per spell level increases by {@damage 1d12}. This damage ignores resistance and immunity.

subclassFeature.name: School of Illusion
entries: You focus your studies on magic that dazzles the senses, befuddles the mind, and tricks even the wisest folk. Your magic is subtle, but the illusions crafted by your keen mind make the impossible seem real. Some illusionists—including many gnome wizards—are benign tricksters who use their spells to entertain. Others are more sinister masters of deception, using their illusions to frighten and fool others for their personal gain.

subclassFeature.name: Dual Illusions
entries: Beginning at 2nd level, when you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} an illusion spell that can create a sensory effect, you can create an additional effect for a different sense. For example, if you create a visual effect, you can also create a sound or smell to accompany it. The additional sensory effect cannot be harmful and must follow any rules and restrictions of the spell cast whenever possible.

subclassFeature.name: Malleable Illusions
entries: Starting at 6th level, the range and duration of all of your illusion spells doubles, and during the duration of an illusion spell you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast}, you can use your action to change the nature of that illusion (using the spell's normal parameters for the illusion), provided that you can see the illusion.

subclassFeature.name: Illusory Self
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you can create an illusory duplicate of yourself as an instant, almost instinctual reaction to danger. When a creature makes an attack roll against you, you can use your reaction to interpose the illusory duplicate between the attackers and yourself. All attacks against you are at {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|disadvantage} until the end of your next turn, then the illusion dissipates.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of one), and you regain all uses on a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Illusory Reality
entries: By 14th level, you have learned the secret of weaving shadow magic into your illusions to give them a semi-reality. When you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} an illusion spell, you can choose one inanimate, nonmagical object that is part of the illusion and make that object real. You can do this on your turn as a bonus action while the spell is ongoing. The object remains real for a number of minutes equal to your Intelligence modifier + your proficiency bonus (minimum of one), and at any time during the duration, you can use your bonus action to end it early. For example, you can create an illusion of a bridge over a chasm and then make it real long enough for your allies to cross.
The object can't deal damage or otherwise directly harm anyone.

subclassFeature.name: School of Necromancy
entries: The School of Necromancy explores the cosmic forces of life, death, and undeath. As you focus your studies in this tradition, you learn to manipulate the energy that animates all living things. As you progress, you learn to sap the life force from a creature as your magic destroys its body, transforming that vital energy into magical power you can manipulate.

Most people see necromancers as menacing, or even villainous, due to the close association with death. Not all necromancers are evil, but the forces they manipulate are considered taboo by many societies.

subclassFeature.name: Grim Harvest
entries: At 2nd level, you gain the ability to reap life energy from creatures you damage with your spells. Once per turn when you damage a creature with a spell, you gain temporary hit points equal to the spell level, and half the damage dealt if it is a necromancy spell or the spell deals necrotic damage. The minimum of the temporary hit points gained is one, so long as the spell is not a cantrip. The temporary hit points gained from this feature last until you take a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

This feature improves at higher levels. At 6th level, any creatures summoned or created by a necromancy spell you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} gain temporary hit points equal to half the damage dealt by them. At 10th level, you gain temporary hit points equal to twice the spell level, and the damage dealt if it is a necromancy spell or the spell deals necrotic damage, and any creatures summoned or created by a necromancy spell you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} gain temporary hit points equal to the damage dealt by them. The minimum of the temporary hit points gained is two, so long as the spell is not a cantrip. At 14th level, anytime this feature triggers, both you and any creatures summoned or created by a necromancy spell you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} gain the temporary hit points, if you are both within 60 feet of each other.

subclassFeature.name: Undead Thralls
entries: At 6th level, the range and duration of all of your necromancy spells doubles, and when you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} a necromancy spell that creates or summons an undead creature, you can create or summon an additional undead creature, following the effects and restrictions of the spell.
Any undead creatures under your direct control gains these benefits:

items: The creature's hit point maximum is increased by an amount equal to your wizard level + your Intelligence modifier + your proficiency bonus + the spell's level (minimum of one).
The creature adds your Intelligence modifier (minimum of one) to its damage. If you would already add your Intelligence modifier to its damage, then you add it again.
Damage dealt by the creature is considered magical for the purpose of overcoming resistances and immunities.

subclassFeature.name: Grim Harvest Improvement
entries: At 6th level, any creatures summoned or created by a necromancy spell you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} gain temporary hit points equal to half the damage dealt by them.

subclassFeature.name: Inured to Undeath
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you have resistance to necrotic and poison damage, and your hit point maximum can't be reduced. Additionally, you gain {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} on death saving throws and saving throws against poison, and the death save DC of all death saving throws decreases by one.

subclassFeature.name: Grim Harvest Improvement
entries: At 10th level, you gain temporary hit points equal to twice the spell level, and the damage dealt if it is a necromancy spell or the spell deals necrotic damage, and any creatures summoned or created by a necromancy spell you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} gain temporary hit points equal to the damage dealt by them. The minimum of the temporary hit points gained is two, so long as the spell is not a cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Command Undead
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use magic to bring undead under your control, even those created by other necromancers. As an action, you can choose one undead that you can see within 60 feet of you. That creature must make a Charisma saving throw against your wizard spell save DC. If it succeeds, you can't use this feature on it again. If it fails, it becomes friendly to you and obeys your commands until you use this feature again, and it is treated as if it was created or summoned by you.

Intelligent undead are harder to control in this way. If the target has an Intelligence of 8 or higher, it has {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} on the saving throw. If it fails the saving throw and has an Intelligence of 12 or higher, it can repeat the saving throw at the end of every hour until it succeeds and breaks free.
Additionally, if it would normally require an action or bonus action to command undead under your control, you can do so mentally without using your action or bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Grim Harvest Improvement
entries: At 14th level, anytime this feature triggers, both you and any creatures summoned or created by a necromancy spell you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} gain the temporary hit points, if you are both within 60 feet of each other.

subclassFeature.name: School of Transmutation
entries: You are a student of spells that modify energy and matter. To you, the world is not a fixed thing, but eminently mutable, and you delight in being an agent of change. You wield the raw stuff of creation and learn to alter both physical forms and mental qualities. Your magic gives you the tools to become a smith on reality's forge.

Some transmuters are tinkerers and pranksters, turning people into toads and transforming copper into silver for fun and occasional profit. Others pursue their magical studies with deadly seriousness, seeking the power of the gods to make and destroy worlds.

subclassFeature.name: Minor Alchemy
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can transform materials into simple items. You conduct an hour-long ritual that crafts a nonmagical item: a {@filter simple or martial weapon|items|source=|type=simple weapon;martial weapon|rarity=none}, a {@filter suit of armor|items|source=|type=heavy armor;medium armor;light armor|rarity=none}, ten pieces of {@filter ammunition|items|source=|type=ammunition|rarity=none}, a {@filter set of tools|items|source=|type=artisan's tools;tools|rarity=none}, or another object. The creation is completed at the end of the hour, coalescing in an unoccupied space of your choice on a surface within 5 feet of you. The thing you create can be something that is worth no more than 100 gp and you must have seen it before. As part of this ritual, you must lay out the same type of materials that the item is made of, which can include coins if the item is made out of metal, with a value equal to the creation. The material irretrievably coalesces and transforms into the creation at the ritual's end, magically forming even parts of the creation that does not include the type of material the rest of the item is made out of. The ritual can create a duplicate of a nonmagical item, such as a key, if you possess the original during the ritual.
After using this feature once, you cannot use it again until you take a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Transmuter's Stone
entries: Starting at 6th level, the range and duration of all of your transmutation spells doubles, and you can spend 8 hours creating a transmuter's stone that stores transmutation magic. You can benefit from the stone yourself or give it to another creature. A creature gains the benefits of the stone as long as the stone is in the possession of the wearer. The stone grants the wearer two of the following benefits:

items: {@sense Darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet. If the wearer already has {@sense darkvision}, then this extends it by 60 feet. They can also see through magical darkness that is within their {@sense darkvision}.
An increase to their speed by 10 feet.

Proficiency in Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throws (your choice whenever you create the transmuter's stone). If the creature is already proficient in the chosen saving throw, they gain {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} when making the chosen saving throw instead.
Resistance to acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage (your choice whenever you create the transmuter's stone).

entries: You can pick a benefit multiple times. Each time you {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} a transmutation spell of 1st level or higher, you can change the effects of the stone if it is within 30 feet, or the range of the spell (whichever is higher). If you create a new transmuter's stone, the previous one ceases to function. At 10th level, you can choose three benefits, and at 14th level, you can choose four benefits.

subclassFeature.name: Master Transmuter
entries: At 10th level, you can {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast} one of your {@subclassFeature Transmutation Tradition Spells|Wizard|PHB|Transmutation|WHW|2|WHW|Tradition Spells} without expending a spell slot once per long rest. If you want to upcast the spell, you must expend a spell slot as normal.

Additionally, during a long rest, you can replace one of your {@subclassFeature Transmutation Tradition Spells|Wizard|PHB|Transmutation|WHW|2|WHW|Tradition Spells} with {@filter a transmutation spell from any spell list|spells|source=|school=t}, but the spell chosen must be the same level as the {@subclassFeature Transmutation Tradition Spells|Wizard|PHB|Transmutation|WHW|2|WHW|Tradition Spell} you replaced it with.

subclassFeature.name: Transmuter's Stone Improvement
entries: At 10th level, you can choose three benefits.

subclassFeature.name: Magnum opus
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use your action to consume the reserve of transmutation magic stored within your transmuter's stone in a single burst. When you do so, choose one of the following effects. Your transmuter's stone is destroyed and can't be remade until you finish a long rest.

items.name: Major Transformation
entries: You create one nonmagical item of your choice in an unoccupied space within 20 feet of you. The item must appear on a surface or in a liquid that can support it. The gp value of the item can't be more than 40 times your wizard level, and the item must be a nonmagical object that you have seen that is Huge or smaller. You can have only one item created by this feature at a time; if you use this action and already have an item from this feature, the first one immediately vanishes.

items.name: Panacea
entries: You remove all curses, diseases, and poisons affecting a creature that you touch with the transmuter's stone. The creature also regains all its hit points.

items.name: Restore Life
entries: You cast the {@spell Raise Dead} spell as an action on a creature you touch with the transmuter's stone, without expending a spell slot, material components, or needing to have the spell in your spellbook.

items.name: Restore Youth
entries: You touch the transmuter's stone to a willing creature, and that creature's apparent age is reduced by {@dice 3d10} years, to a minimum of 18 years, or the equivalent for the creature's race. This effect extends the creature's lifespan by the same amount of time its age is reduced.

subclassFeature.name: Transmuter's Stone Improvement
entries: At 14th level, you can choose four benefits.

variantrule.name: Tradition Spells
entries: Each tradition has a list of spells—its tradition spells—that you gain at the wizard levels noted in the tradition description. Once you gain a tradition spell, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. The spell does not need to be in your spell book to {@action cast a spell|PHB|cast}.
If you have a tradition spell that doesn't appear on the wizard spell list, the spell is nonetheless a wizard spell for you.

data.name: Arcane Traditions
entries: The study of wizardry is ancient, stretching back to the earliest mortal discoveries of magic. It is firmly established in the worlds of D&D, with various traditions dedicated to its complex study.

The most common arcane traditions in the multiverse revolve around the {@book schools of magic|PHB|10|The Schools of Magic}. Wizards through the ages have catalogued thousands of spells, grouping them into eight categories called schools. In some places, these traditions are literally schools; a wizard might study at the School of Illusion while another studies across town at the School of Enchantment. In other institutions, the schools are more like academic departments, with rival faculties competing for students and funding. Even wizards who train apprentices in the solitude of their own towers use the division of magic into schools as a learning device, since the spells of each school require mastery of different techniques.
